Fellow South Carolinian & taker of prescribed medication here: PLEASE don't share your medication with your friends. I'm not trying to be judgmental, but if you are not prescribed a certain medication, don't take it! It's not cute or funny to share meds with friends, and it makes those who need them to function look less valid. Besides all of the other messy things in this diary, this is what irked me the most.
as soon as she left the ativan for her friend...

Ativan is a controlled substance and can be extremely dangerous, particularly when mixed with other substances including alcohol. (It was in Michael Jackson and Heath Ledger's systems when they died).  I have never commented on a MD before, but PLEASE do better than sharing this with people. What if that person got sick during this time and had to seek medical attention during this outbreak?  This seriously made me cringe. Do better, OP.

Pharmacist here... please don’t share your medicine.  That is completely irresponsible.  Yes, many people are having anxiety now.  There is a lot going on in the world, but it’s not your job to give away a controlled substance.  You know you can be arrested for that if you got caught, right?  Not to mention the obvious...are you a doctor who can diagnose your friend if she actually needs that medicine or if it will be safe for her to take?  People sharing their drugs with people just contributes to the problems we have today with drug addiction, dependence and abuse.  Shame on you for making a joke about it.

I think OP has good intentions, but there were a lot of social-distancing missteps here that I didn't like. Your daughter should not be visiting her grandparents, for one - I understand parenting while working is challenging, but that's what you signed up for when you had her. Also, even though your fever is gone, you and everyone in your household need to completely isolate for at least a week and treat it as if you had COVID, because you easily could. (Per CDC guidelines, if you have COVID symptoms, your household shouldn't interact with others again until you've been fever free for 72 hours w/o meds AND other symptoms have improved AND it's been at least 7 days since your symptoms started).

OP here (braving the roast): first, thanks for all the parents who are struggling along with me to pivot in to a whole new world of stress and responsibilities. Caring for another person is hard, whether it’s a child or a parent or any other loved one. Second: I am well aware about my privilege and my “suburban drug deal” comment was tongue-in-cheek. Not many of you caught my comment about commiserating with my friends over first world problems (because I know that’s all we have). Many people have it much worse. However, this was a snap-shot of what my life is like, and I’m not going to apologize for not having the same struggles as others. I do my best to raise my child with awareness of her innate privilege and the responsibilities it brings to do our best to recognize and empathize with the lives of others. All I can do is continue to listen and defend when I witness acts of injustice. Thirdly, to the ‘drug deal’ itself: I one hundred percent realize that it is illegal and potentially unsafe. I also used to share alcohol (when I was underage!) with my friends, and I never have gotten my weed tested at a lab to make sure it wasn’t mixed with anything. Heaven forbid, I’ve also taken mushrooms, and some tabs of acid, too! And I shared them! (Cont. below)

You are a nightmare of a human being who is casually passing out medication that can be EXTREMELY DANGEROUS if not used correctly as prescribed BY A MEDICAL PROFESSIONAL, and you are endangering your nanny, your mother-in-law, and probably a bunch of other people. Do better.

I'm sorry but OP, you have some very problematic habits that you need to straighten out, including, but not limited to: - spending as much on non-essentials as you are when you have $237,000 in debt - violating social distancing in about 913345 ways - drug dealing?!?! - demonstrating a complete lack of self-awareness by openly admitting to a felony online, and brushing it off as a "suburban drug deal" - not being able to figure out how to make dinner without a meal kit  Your ignorant and privilege-filled post entirely encapsulates the injustice of mass incarceration. People of color get prison sentences all the time for less than what you did. You distributed a drug that you had a prescription for to someone who didn't, which the law considers to be a felony (as opposed to possession, which is a much lighter crime in the eyes of the law). Moreover, you might think "Ativan is a harmless suburban/white collar drug that's totally different from something like cocaine," but you would be completely wrong. Ativan is a benzodiazepine. In medical school we call these benzos for short. In our substance abuse course in med school, we spent around 10x the amount of time on benzos as on cocaine. Why? Because benzos not only cause overdose deaths (especially when mixed with alcohol), but also cause *withdrawal deaths*. Cocaine doesn't cause withdrawal, but benzodiazepines do, and that can be fatal. Using benzodiazepines in the absence of a medical diagnosis is incredibly irresponsible.

For all of you out there that think fulltime RVing is great. Remember, unless you've got an enormous amount of money put away to live on after your in your 60s. It not a good idea to quit your job and take off. There are bunches of people out there that have done that without thinking ahead about there life when they're old. The older you get the more medical situations show up. Most people below 40 don't realize this. We been RVing for 12 years now. and we are retired so our trips are 3 to 5 months at a time. So we're pretty much fulltiming it when we're on the road. We don't have to worry about this covid 19 because we didn't sell our house. We paid it off before we started RVing.   We waited till we were debt free to do it. We worked hard to be able to do pretty much anything we want to do and we don't have to worry about money. Were 71 now and have years to RV left. If you can work from home then fulltime RVing is possible. Otherwise don't quit your day job to try this.  Most people doing this are not going to tell you anything negative because it won't make them look like they made the right decisions.   Save up the money and pay off the house and cars and credit cards. And research RVs for at least a year before buying one. All RVs break down whether they're new or not. It can be a good thing to buy used because someone else has paid for the problems they have. We pull a 37 foot 5th wheel with a Silverado crew-cab long bed truck. 7 solar panels and 4-300 amp batteries.

I know that everyone feels and handles things differently and is entitled to do so. This is not a criticism, but I didn't understand why OP was so stressed and overwhelmed. She is is in a supportive and loving relationship. She is on her way to owning a house in one of the world's most sought after and beautiful cities. She has no children to worry over and care for. She hates her job, as sadly many, many people do. But her job allows her to work from home and leave most days at 5:00. She has leisure time for reading books and friends. At age 31, her salary is much higher than the average 50 year old's salary. Her commute is challenging, but as are many people's commutes, whether stuck in cars for long periods of time, hoping to fend off road rage incidents or crammed into commuter trains and buses praying not to contact COVID 19. Most commenters seem to agree that OP's life is stressful. What am I missing? Maybe I'm just envious; but I would love to have her problems, in comparison to the ones I or those around me have.

is it just me, or does anyone else get annoyed by diaries that are spanning ‘abnormal’ weeks? like this was not a normal week for her because her parents were in town, so she’s going out to dinner/doing activities more than she normally does and paying less than she normally would. the restaurant bills were high, but she was barely paying anything. in a regular week, she’d most likely pay her share of a probably smaller bill.  similar to the diary the other week where she was at a conference the whole time. these aren’t their typical spending habits and don’t really give us a good look at what daily life is like for someone making $XX,XXX in that specific city.

Anyone else have parents who expect them (the adult-child) to pay? I wish my parents would cover our meals out lol. That said, I noticed that OP qualifies every Chinese restaurant she goes to as “upscale” but doesn’t do the same with any of the other type of (euro/American) cuisine she eats. This implies (whether it’s implicit bias or not) that Chinese food is not usually or cannot, in and of itself, be upscale. It’s the same logic where people are okay paying $500 for a French meal but scoff at some Chinese dishes being “too expensive.” Considering all the anti- Chinese sentiment (racism, xenophobia) right now I think it’s a) a weird choice to publish this diary while ignoring this gaff and b) not address the implicit bias.

I'm an epidemiologist who volunteered as a contact tracer for the occupational health department at our big hospital system. Past tense because there were so many cases among health care workers, occupational health gave up on contact tracing.  Your partner has been exposed. It's nearly a given. I can't tell you how many clinicians (e.g., people who theoretically know what to look for) from nurses to respiratory therapists to attending physicians to department heads and everyone in between who kept coming to work despite having "a tickle in their throat" (sometimes for WEEKS even) that later led to a positive COVID-19 test. If not a positive patient, then a coworker. If not this week, then next. I would really urge to think of it not as a possibility, but as an inevitability and the question is only when.  It's the worst, because obviously there's no option to not come to work if you're serving in such an essential role. But it means you, OP, can't just be careful, you have to be militant about precautions and distancing. Please sit down and take the time to take a hard look at how much contact and how much risk you're actually running here.

I also am a social worker and am having to continue face-to-face visits (different state). Since I continue to have so much contact with families (some of which are considered high-risk), my fiancé and I do not have any extra contact with ANYONE. We have been having everything delivered and try to go on runs in the most deserted places possible and at off-times. We have friends and family we'd love to see, but it's 100% not responsible to continue seeing them when I'm exposing myself, and others, daily. It's already a challenge to do what we can to protect ourselves and our families while doing visits, but all it takes is for one asymptomatic person to spread it and dozens are affected - and that's just in my circle. This is NOT the time to be taking risk when you literally work in a life preserving profession.

Since OP and her boyfriend are too dense to figure it out on their own, the point of social distancing and other measures is to prevent you from spreading the virus as much as it’s about preventing you from contracting the virus. Hospitals are literally telling healthcare providers that PPE is to protect PATIENTS from THEM, not the other way around. If boyfriend miraculously never picks up the virus at the hospital, he might get it from Costco or from OP or from OP’s roommate, and then pass it on to a patient or a coworker who sees patients. The lack of cases in his particular department should be something he wants to safeguard, not “permission” to go on frivolous visits and errands. It’s absolutely horrifying that OP and her boyfriend chose these careers presumably to help others yet they can only think of themselves. Wow.

OP hereeee I saw a couple questions asking for updates. My school updated us and now we are indefinitely postponed. They said that we will get the "green light" once local schools re-open, then teachers will have 3 weeks to get back to Chengdu. My fiance is still displaced in the south of China and the plan is for him to go back to Chengdu this month, update me, and I will make my way back. Those $280 tickets I scouted are now over $900 which makes me think I missed my window to get back to Chengdu.  This outbreak is going nuts in the US right now (deja vu?) and today is the day my siblings drove into town and we are remembering my mom. One sister and husband decided they will stay here for a week or as long as they need to (working from home). The other and her husband are heading back because his work isn't cancelled (.. yet! We have a bet).  I couldn't just take more students or rearrange my schedule because people who have been in lockdown in China and not working are not dishing out $$$ for online tutoring. Thankful for my normal paycheck+the editing+barebones of tutoring.  The wedding might be off? We still don't know.  Due to my mom's illness last year, we have a weirdly large amount of leftover medical supplies including masks and rubbing alcohol and rubber gloves, so I'm feeling prepped.  My dad and whole family are very healthy, so we are just going to sit and wait. Thanks for encouragement, guys. I was so anxious about getting murdered in the comments!!!

I feel like so many of the diarists who are in debt claim that the week they log happens to be an unusually high spend one. That cannot be true. I have some debt and the key is to be honest with yourself about your spending habits. It may be an unusually high week, fine, but then how many of those weeks are you having over the course of the year? If you even say perhaps one week a month is unusual, add to that some emergencies or some one off spend requirements - boom, you’re in debt.

Hey OP, enjoyed this diary and your honesty about getting your finances in order! It's not easy to acknowledge areas that need some work and it sounds like you're doing a great job getting on top of it- awesome!  Just a tip that's worked for me: Try setting up your paycheck so that at least a small amount is deposited into a different account, or even multiple accounts. It's such an easy way to save money without trying, AND it psychologically makes you feel like you have less play money to spend in your checking account. Also it seems like the student loans/CC debt doesn't have to be an either/or thing...for example you could divert $250 of each paycheck into a separate account just to start chipping away at that. Best of luck, you're doing great!

Hi! OP here. Wow, you think you've spent all this time and effort on a money diaries and then you read it and realize how much you missed!  Some stuff:  1) I invest 15% towards retirement (pre-tax) 2) I receive $2,400 a year from a family member for my student loans which I just received, so I now have 3K left. I have a CC debt snowball for the credit cards and have done a pretty good job of strategically timing out my payments so that by I'm CC debt free by Oct 2021, well before my 0% APR hits. I'm choosing to pay my student loans off first because I have a huge fear that I won't be able to get my shit together regarding my spending and I'm just afraid that I'll get myself out of CC debt and then slide right back in. At least my student loans will be GONE in 4 months. I recognize how tenuous it seems and honestly I have a lot of shame around this, but I'm doing really good in regards to working on this.  3) I did stop home for 30 minutes to hang with my dog between work & the shelter! She also has my roommate & her bf at home for some socialization. But I do feel bad for these long days.  4) My insurance is under my mom, which probably helps with the lower cost.

Fellow user of out-of-network therapists here: just wanted to note what I recently found out about coverage for out-of-network services after you hit your deductible.  Although your plan probably states 70% covered, it usually means 70% of the <strong allowable amount</strong  is covered.  The allowable amount is usually calculated by reference to the Medicare rates for services (multiplied by some amount, e.g., 120%, 130%).  That's a long way of saying to prepare for the fact that insurance might not cover 70% of your $185 therapy sessions.  It might be closer to 70% of $120 - depends on how your sessions are coded.

I'm reluctant to weigh in here but based on my limited experience, I think OP is choosing a very, very difficult path for herself - especially if one or both of her parents need care as they age. My husband had four separate foot surgeries over a three-year period, and spent months on crutches during each recovery time. He was powerless to physically do much of anything around the house, and he couldn't drive...and mentally, he would often get down about the lack of mobility and the isolation at home. I would get way frustrated at times - in part because my widowed mom also had needs - but felt like I couldn't show it. He was already feeling like a burden and I didn't want him to feel that way. I would remind myself that this was a temporary situation. We've been married for over 10 years and to me, this is just part of the drill - but starting off married life knowing that the person you chose will likely never be able to help carry the weight, to hold a job etc. is another thing entirely - especially if OP wants children down the road.
Where are D’s parents? I realize not everyone has the privilege to get help from their parents but OP is so young and all the burden is on her unfortunately.

I am a mental health provider and also have an immediate family member with a debilitating mental illness, and so many of these comments are breaking my heart.  It sounds like OP's fiancé likely takes antipsychotics which means that he probably has schizophrenia, schizoaffective disorder, or another severe mental illness.  For those who are implying or stating that he is a lazy, freeloading man-baby really need to check their ableist assumptions at the door.  Can it be challenging to be in a relationship with someone with a severe mental illness?  Can there be significant caregiving responsibilities involved?  Yes and yes.  For folks with these illnesses, sometimes just making it through the day is an huge challenge.  The illnesses themselves are serious, and the drugs to treat them also come with a host of significant side effects.  Fatigue, mental confusion, slowed processing, and flat affect all can result from the illness or from the drugs.  Those of you who are implying that he should just buck up, make an effort, and get a job should really spend some time educating yourselves.  NAMI is a great place to start.  Some people with  mental/emotional disabilities can certainly work but some truly cannot.  We don't know the history of their relationship, why she has chosen to be with him, or what agreements they have around caregiving.  But please take a moment and think about how you are talking about people with mental illness or disabilities, even if you are concerned.

Hi OP! I also have a partner with a severe mental illness. Luckily, he is on SSDI and we have not had issues yet (knock on wood). I'm of course still the main earner though.  It can be really challenging to be in a relationship like this! I was 21 when he and I started dating, and once finances got real around my mid-twenties, it was stressful to realize that being in a relationship with him meant being the primary earner, maybe forever.   What helped us a lot was really re-framing things so that we are always sharing responsibilities. Yes, I may be the one who pays for the majority of our rent, but it's both of our responsibilities to make sure that we can, together, afford our living costs. If my income goes down, together we need to figure out how we're going to make ends meet. He knows our income and expenses, and finds ways to cut things where possible. He does things like manages all of our subscription services for us (though I think this is partly because I'm not great at unsubscribing when not using something. Looking at you, STARZ!). There are plenty of ways to step-up that don't involve being the breadwinner, and him doing these things has been really good for both of us.   He's truly a partner to me, even without working, between chores, moral support as I get through a master's program, and more. Now, we're engaged, and I look forward to doing eventually our taxes together, look into different options for saving and investing, etc.

As the operations manager of an ABA program, I have to say that there is NO reliable research to support the use of a Registered Behavior Technician for direct intervention purposes via telehealth. The only data that supports telehealth in ABA is from a BCBA-level clinician, and only in the context of parent training. If an RBT is going to be used, it should be via synchronous telehealth with the BCBA at the distant site providing real time feedback and analysis, which would still require you to go into the patient's home. So... this doesn't make sense to me.  Nonetheless, ABA therapists are highly susceptible to job burn out and often the victims of employers taking advantage of labor law loop holes. You have a lot on your plate so I hope you work for an ethical organization. Leave if you don't.

I am 99.99% sure that she is a Registered Technician and NOT an ABA Therapist. Therapists have a much larger salary, and you have to complete grad school for that title. Grad students usually work as RTs in grad school to complete their clinical hours while getting paid. I’m doing the same thing right now, I’d never call myself a therapist until I actually was.

I think many of the commenters here unfairly are tearing the OP down for traveling to SF and living her life.  It's incredibly easy to judge her based what we know NOW, but you all seem to be forgetting how quickly things changed in the span of 3 weeks.    Based on the Daylight Savings, her trip to SF was from Friday, March 6 to Monday, March 9.  Most Americans by March 5th (the day before her trip) were very much aware of Coronavirus, but many did not quite understand how severe or contagious it is.  Most young adults were dismissive of it or at least not particularly concerned with protecting themselves.  Combined with Trump Administration's ineffective messaging on COVID-19 (essentially "not a big deal, don't panic, just wash your hands"), one can see why OP decided to continue living her life as normal.  I live near SF.  I was supposed to get married in early May of this year.  In the first week of March, I thought things would "blow over" by the end of April and my wedding would go on, albeit with a smaller guest list.  By March 16, I was no longer confident and was forced to cancel my wedding.  THAT'S HOW FAST THINGS CHANGED.

Thank you for this update! I really like your writing. I just want to add a few thoughts to the tax/medical care issue. Disclaimer, I am from Central Europe so a lot of the American discourse on taxes and especially the “you only deserve what you pay” mentality  sounds outright crazy to me. 1. Tax equality is not only about taxing earnings proportionally. If you have fixed taxes, such as value added taxes for food and stuff, high earners have a proportionally lower tax burden. Same if you don’t tax certain things that are more common with wealthy people, such as earnings from interest. I am sure that proportionally to your income, you don’t pay a lesser percentage in taxes. 2. The right to receive medical care should never ever be tied to contributions. Which is why a state cannot be run like a company. Please don’t ever feel shame for receiving medical care. It is a states responsibility for its citizens to provide it and the real shame in my opinion is that so many countries are failing in that aspect.
I love all the details this time OP!!!

“If I worked harder and made more money, Medicaid wouldn't have covered my surgery — it's like the system punishes people for being middle class.“   Latter part is true, but it’s not about you or your work. Lots of people work long hours and still earn so little they qualify for Medicaid. It may be an unpopular truth, but the system just punishes everyone who isn’t wealthy.

R29: the "net worth" field as-is is pretty darn useless.  it seems no one really knows how to calculate it. refer to the diarists with 200K+ in student and consumer debt who then have a positive net worth listed. unless these people somehow also have hundreds of thousands of equity in their homes or massive trust funds, this can't possibly be right.  what would be much more meaningful (and likely more consistently calculated) is an inventory of assets. for example, here she says she has $100K net worth. is that tied up in a home she owns? 401K? liquid assets? did she inherit it? saying "my net worth is $100k" is not at all useful information in painting a financial picture...especially for a 25 year old making $80k a year

OP, I've moved to a new city for a job without knowing anyone, and was totally isolated. It was the worst two years of my life, and yes it took two years to make any progress in forming lasting relationships. I also had debt that reduced my ability to do social things to try to make friends. Don't discount how tough what you're going through is, and give yourself credit for small successes. I remember going to a park on a beautiful spring day and just sitting alone and crying behind my sunglasses while watching all of these people have friendships. It was miserable, but also therapeutic. Allow your emotions to be felt, and don't feel badly for them. Your people will stand by you and understand what you're going through. I hope things get better for you soon.

OP, I know you called it out yourself but just to stress the matter: you my dear are very depressed. I don't think therapy should be an 'optional' expense for you. Maybe you can spend some of this lockdown time searching for new therapists within your insurance group, or reworking your budget to continue with your current one. Also, I'm an avid proponent for marijuana and personally use for insomnia too , but marijuana is a downer aka a depressant. Its not good to partake when you're depressed. Lastly, LA is a hard city to make friends in but I think you should make more effort to do so through intramural sports, meetups for people that are into what you're into, maybe hang with some friends of your friend who moved from LA to SF, maybe a happy hour with a co-worker who is somewhat cool... Please try to find some joy for yourself. I wish you all the best.

Oh pal, I'm so sorry you're having such a hard time! I'm a super extrovert who lives alone and is working from home through all this and it's TOUGH, so I feel you. Some things I've found that help: going for walks, either in my neighborhood or in parks; finding the right balance/amount of weed and wine to help me relax without just making me depressed; participating in virtual yoga and dance classes; reconnecting with friends I don't talk to much via phone or FaceTime; talking to my mom every otherish day; trying to eat right (I got on the scale yesterday and...oof); and (most importantly) limiting my intake of news and social media. I went down a rabbit hole Friday and ended up calling my parents in hysterical tears Friday night, convinced that I was going to be stuck in my house for two years. This time sucks and is scary, but we'll get through it. Sending you all the love!

Just want to add a different perspective on the relationship. I was in a very similar situation to you 5 years ago, OP. I'm American, my boyfriend is European, we met and spent a very short amount of time together, did long distance for a year, and then I moved to Europe (I had the flexible job). Long distance is TOUGH, but I also want to point out that cultural differences can be huge, especially in communication (read: fighting!). This is something that took a LONG TIME for my boyfriend and I to work through, and it was really hard, but we got on the same page eventually. Adding to this, I was pretty young, wasn't sure what I wanted to do in life, and I was nervous about leaving all my friends and family and American life behind! But something kept telling me to keep going with him, even when it got tough.   5 years later, we still live in Europe, we are getting married later this year, and although I'm not really one to spout ~soulmates~, I can tell you that he is simply the best lifemate I could have chosen.   YOU DO YOU, girl, but just wanted to share my story. There are lots of guys out there, for sure. Only YOU know what's best!

I never comment on MDs, but this one really highlights the importance of exercise and eating healthy. I highly recommend downloading the Peloton app. It's not just for spin classes, but has yoga and bodyweight strength training. They are doing a 90 day free trial right now. My unsolicited advice is that making some type of routine would really help, especially if you start the day off with a quick workout.   On food, I get that we are living in an apocalyptic time with grocery stores being crowded and disease-ridden, but if the store is a 30 minute walk, go walk there twice a week. Keep your distance from others, lysol wipe the cart down and wash your hands before and after the trip. But as long as it's not raining, I dont see what the downside of a 30 minute walk to the store is. Plus, it would double as exercise. You clearly have a lot of free time, so time is not an excuse!

OP, I just wanted to pop in and offer some support. I went through the same thing about just over a year ago, and had to have the LEEP procedure. I was 26 at the time. It was super stressful and I have totally been in your shoes. A couple of things that helped me: my OBGYN recommended I start taking a supplement called Oncovite, which I started taking before the procedure... when they biopsied the tissue they removed from me, my doc told me that the abnormal cells were gone, and I’ve had clear paps ever since. I absolutely know everyone has a different experience and no two bodies are the same, but I wanted to share some of my experience and offer a bit of hope. Secondly, I strongly believe that my aggressive efforts to drastically minimize the stress in my life played a huge role in keeping me healthy. I was also working as a designer, and also had dreams of becoming a freelance photographer full-time. I think my job was putting invisible stress on me, and ironically when I did quit that job and start freelancing (which is what I do now, full time) it took away the stress...I think because I am earning more, even though it isn’t a “steady” paycheck.  It is incredible what stress can do to the body, and we have to take care of our whole selves.

Please, please, please make sure to have regular anal exams in addition to vaginal exams and cervical Pap smears. I had multiple abnormal Pap’s and LEEP procedures 15 years ago and was recently diagnosed with anal cancer, which is also caused by HPV.  I never had any anal exams because I wasn’t practicing anal sex so the cancer had been growing there all these years.  If you haven’t already, get the HPV vaccine. It’s FDA approved for women to age 45 now. I’ve had surgery and radiation and the cancer might still come back. All of this could have been completely prevented.

Hi OP! I’m sorry you had to go through such a painful/annoying medical procedure twice, not to mention deal with the fear and uncertainty.   I just want to say, there’s no such thing as an “immune boosting diet”. Any diet that claims to boost your immune system is pseudoscience. There are of course plenty of other reasons to eat vitamin-filled fruits and veggies, as well as lean protein sources, so there’s no harm in that.   I totally understand wanting to try something that claims to boost your immune system or claims to be “anti-cancer.”  Illness and cancer are scary, and it would be nice to think we could cure them with magic diets. It just doesn’t work that way (though certain cancers.. eg colon cancer.. are linked to certain less healthy diets).   I hope you got the answers you wanted from your colposcopy. Also don’t be afraid to switch doctors to find one who talks to you more. Listening to your patients is arguably one of the most important things for a doctor to do.

In my mid-20's I had several abnormal paps and got diagnosed with strains 16 and 18 of HPV. Also had a colonoscopy and was given all of the general advice about the body naturally clearing HPV. I'm now 30 and the last few paps I've had have been clear!  One thing that I don't see mentioned in this thread and that finally clicked for me was that even if you are taking all of the vitamins in this world, reducing your stress etc. if you're still sleeping with the same guy and not using condoms, chances are that you will continue to be reinfected with the HPV.  My gyno had advised me that I should be using condoms with my boyfriend, at least until I'd cleared the virus, I ignored her advice at that time. It wasn't until I broke up with the boyfriend I was with during my abnormal paps that I noticed that all my paps since about 6 months post breakup have been clear. Honestly everything else about my lifestyle and health has stayed the same.  This might be obvious, but I wanted to share what I've learned from my own experience (and lack of listening to professionals in the first place!) in case it makes a difference to someone going through the stress of abnormal paps :)

OP, I immediately stopped reading to comment when I got done with day one. I'm 25, and have been getting abnormal pap smears for the last several years because I have high-risk HPV. I have strains 16 and 18, the two strains that have the highest possibility to make my cervical cells become cancerous. I'm surprised that you had a colposcopy done at 23—that's pretty young, and most gynos don't recommend those until you're at least 25 because your immune system is stronger when you're younger. I got my first colposcopy done this year, and it was the scariest thing I've ever had to do. My results from my colposcopy (to make a very long, boring story short) stated that even though I have abnormal cells on my cervix, they're pretty much dormant, so I just need to get a pap smear done every year. As scary and terrifying abnormal paper smears are,I want you to know that it honestly is totally normal. You're doing the right thing in getting it checked out and monitored though. The more you stay on top of it, the higher your recovery is IF they find something in the future. I do want to also reassure you just because you have abnormal cells on your cervix, that doesn't mean that you're GOING to get cervical cancer. It just means those cells COULD. COULD doesn't mean WILL. As long as you're taking good care of yourself, eating right, exercising, doing things to boost your immune system, and going to regular doctor's appointments, I PROMISE you you will be okay. :-) You've got this!

I wanted to share my opinion on your husband's reactions in case he's been having things like this happen a lot lately. I was in his same position just over a year ago due to something called Chronic Spontaneous Urticaria - basically random hives and allergic reactions to no specific trigger. My body and immune system were on overdrive largely due to stress and anxiety (I was dealing with unemployment at the time), and I also had a couple of trips to the ER after a few severe reactions. I found that cutting out dairy, soy and gluten made a huge difference in the severity and frequency of my hives, along with taking daily antihistamines.   It's a horrible feeling to have these unknown reactions, but eventually after working with my allergist and naturopath I was able to cut out the antihistamines and replace them with natural supplements, but it's different for every person I've talked to about this condition. I'd recommend looking up support groups on Facebook, and wish you both the best of luck!

I have severe anxiety and OCD and your husband/bf's choking/throat swallowing thing is something I went through. When I have anxiety/OCD bad flare ups I get this weird symptom where I constantly think I am choking - sometimes on food, sometimes on water, sometimes on nothing; also it feels like I have lumps and obstructions in my throat. I have gone to the ER for it multiple times, I ended up in ENT physical therapy. My physical therapist realized it was psychological and had me do a swallow test where I swallowed food with dye in it so I could see it on an x-ray in a lab and SEE that I had no obstruction and that helped a lot. But basically unless I am on a high dose of antidepressants I get to a point where I feel like I am choking or obstructed all the time.  His panic and then ER visit was very VERY familiar to me. Something to consider.

Hey OP! I did the FODMAP elimination diet/process nearly 3 years ago now for my chronic IBS and it was life-changing! it also helped with my migraines. I reacted to 90% of all FODMAP categories lol so I now follow a low-FODMAP diet, with a few exceptions of food I know I can handle. I did that process with the help of a dietitian and it made such a difference, so I highly recommend seeing if that is an option! Another thing I recommend is downloading the MONASH university app as it tells you what foods you can eat, which ones are high in FODMAPS, and the serving size you can eat, and can filter it to your sensitivities. Good luck, it will be worth it in the long run!

OP here,  I know a lot of people have questions about my diet (because of course we all love talking about food ☺️). I have done multiple elimination diets over the last decade, from weeks to months at a time, and I usually eat a low carb, almost zero sugar, high fat/protein diet. I am confident that dairy and artificial sweeteners are not a trigger for me based on past experiments (I know they’re not ‘good’ for you, but we all need a little vice. As a treat.). I started the FODMAP experiment to identify veggies that are hurting my gut as I usually stick to mostly meats/veggies and I am highly allergic to a lot of fruits which are too high in sugar for me anyways (no more peaches or apples ever!).  As an update- since the time I’ve written this, I have gotten much more on track and will be permanently cutting out cashews, peas, broccoli, and soy (and limiting my artificial sweeteners for good measure- I’m so sad).  I’ve also been continuing to track my spending and it’s crazy how much a specialized diet controls your spending options- I wish I could get by on just a head of cauliflower for dinner and that quality protein was cheaper.   Thanks to everyone who had helpful advice and the other folks who shared their gut issues, I love you all!

Hey OP, I'm so sorry to hear about your job. I hope things get better soon. I just wanted to send you a little bit of motivation and support. I hope you start to feel better.

OP here! I did notice I forgot to mention a few things :) I cleared up some horse money questions in the comments below! Also, my health insurance is 100% employer paid. I'm super grateful for that and being able to get off my family's insurance plan early! I contribute 55$ a month with my employer matching that = $110 a month to my HSA. I use this to cover my monthly chiropractor visits (Back pain, am I right?) and the leftover I plan to invest. My company offers investment plans at the end of each fiscal year to invest "left over" money from your HSA and I plan to take full advantage of that. My retirement is currently 3% of my income for now. I plan to up that come fall. As apart of my hire, I started at $50k a year and in 6 months (September) receive a $5k raise, so that will put my annual salary at $55,000 a year. They will reevaluate my income and put in for another raise once I graduate. I started at my company in June of 2019 as an intern, caught on very quickly, and got the opportunity to come on full time!   You all have been so amazing and supportive in the comments section! I love interacting with everyone and hearing questions or their stories! :)

I suggest doing something in a group regularly as a good way to make friends. Showing up week after week allows you the time to build a friendship, and a common topic to discuss. Sport, volunteering, an adult education course, I speak from experience, are all good ways of making friends.

I'm a 22 year old and I've also noticed that it's hard to make friends my own age in a new place. I think a big factor is that in your early 20s, many people in the area have been there since high school/college, and thus already have established friend groups. As you get older, more people start to move around, and there are more people your age looking for new friends.

To those who are looking at law school like OP- If you think that your first semester will likely be online, I would wait a year. (Although I know it's hard to predict what the world will look like in August).  The first year of law school is hard and causes mental health issues galore- and that is even when you're able to be there in person, to make friends with your classmates, etc. I am graduating from law school in a few weeks and I can't think of anything worse or more challenging than starting your first semester of law school online.  In my opinion, it would be better to wait a year and have an in-person law school experience all the way through.

This comment is not directed to you specifically OP, because you seem like a sweet person who is aware of your privilege.  However, I wish people would use the world "privileged" instead of "lucky" when referring to parental or family support.  "Lucky" makes it sound random, whereas "privileged" acknowledges the systems in place (racism, classism, etc.) that allow some families to accrue and pass on wealth and opportunity to their children.  I say this as a person who has privilege both by birth and by marriage.  I have worked somewhat hard for the things I have, but I have also achieved financial stability and comfort because I have ALWAYS had some sort of safety net, and opportunities available to me because of my privileged status.  Just my two cents and again I don't mean to pick on you OP, I just hope to change the conversation around privilege!

I know it's unsolicited advice, but please look into the essential oils you use. I can tell you love your kitty, but you may not know a lot of EOs are toxic to them, as cats don't have the same liver enzymes humans do, and can't break a lot of them down. It's not about impurities in the oils, it's the oils themselves. Eucalyptus and citrus are some of the most dangerous. Vinegar and baking soda are two cleaning tools that are safe around kitty!

<span data-mention="u_JRTKnfkcgcao,Sprankle,Sprankle" </span  another way to help is to become a respite care worker for foster parents. It’s essentially babysitting children if the parents need to be away for a night. Because of (naturally) strict rules around foster care, foster parents in many states can’t just leave the children with a grandparent or friend, or even hire a teenage babysitter, like biological parents can.   It’s still a big commitment: there are classes, etc., but it isn’t the same commitment as becoming a full-out foster parent. And if you’re considering becoming a foster parent in the future, it might be a good first step.
